abstract: Nox1 and Nox4, homologues of the leukocyte NADPH oxidase subunit Nox2 (gp91phox) mediate superoxide anion formation in various cell types. However, their interactions with other components of the NADPH oxidase are poorly defined. We determined whether a direct interaction of Nox1 and Nox4 with the p22phox subunit of the NADPH oxidase occurs. Using confocal microscopy, co-localization of p22phox with Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4 was observed in transiently transfected vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) and HEK293 cells. Plasmids coding for fluorescent fusion proteins of p22phox and the Nox proteins with cyan- and yellow-fluorescent protein (cfp and yfp, respectively) were constructed and expressed in VSMC and HEK293 cells. The cfp-tagged p22phox expression level increased upon cotransfection with Nox1 or Nox4. Protein-protein interaction between the fluorescent fusion proteins of p22phox and the Nox partners was observed using the fluorescence resonance energy transfer technique. Immunoprecipitation of native Nox1 from human VSMC revealed co-precipitation of p22phox. Immunoprecipitation from transfected HEK293 cells revealed co-precipitation of native p22phox with yfp-tagged Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4. Following mutation of a histidine (corresponding to the position 115 in human Nox2) to leucine, this interaction was abolished. Transfection of rat p22phox (but not Noxo1 and Noxa1) increased the radical generation in cells expressing Nox4. We provide evidence that p22phox directly interacts with Nox1 and Nox4, to form an superoxide-generating NADPH oxidase and demonstrate that mutation of the potential heme binding site in the Nox proteins disrupts the complex formation of Nox1 and Nox4 with p22phox. Nox1 and Nox4, homologues of the leukocyte NADPH oxidase subunit Nox2 (gp91phox) mediate superoxide anion formation in various cell types. However, their interactions with other components of the NADPH oxidase are poorly defined. We determined whether a direct interaction of Nox1 and Nox4 with the p22phox subunit of the NADPH oxidase occurs. Using confocal microscopy, co-localization of p22phox with Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4 was observed in transiently transfected vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) and HEK293 cells. Plasmids coding for fluorescent fusion proteins of p22phox and the Nox proteins with cyan- and yellow-fluorescent protein (cfp and yfp, respectively) were constructed and expressed in VSMC and HEK293 cells. The cfp-tagged p22phox expression level increased upon cotransfection with Nox1 or Nox4. Protein-protein interaction between the fluorescent fusion proteins of p22phox and the Nox partners was observed using the fluorescence resonance energy transfer technique. Immunoprecipitation of native Nox1 from human VSMC revealed co-precipitation of p22phox. Immunoprecipitation from transfected HEK293 cells revealed co-precipitation of native p22phox with yfp-tagged Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4. Following mutation of a histidine (corresponding to the position 115 in human Nox2) to leucine, this interaction was abolished. Transfection of rat p22phox (but not Noxo1 and Noxa1) increased the radical generation in cells expressing Nox4. We provide evidence that p22phox directly interacts with Nox1 and Nox4, to form an superoxide-generating NADPH oxidase and demonstrate that mutation of the potential heme binding site in the Nox proteins disrupts the complex formation of Nox1 and Nox4 with p22phox. The phagocyte NADPH oxidase generates superoxide anions (O–2) by reducing molecular oxygen by a transmembrane heterodimer, which carries two hemes and forms a cytochrome b558 complex (1Babior B.M. Blood. 1999; 93: 1464-1476Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Vignais P.V. CMLS Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2002; 59: 1428-1459Crossref PubMed Scopus (631) Google Scholar). This complex functions as a final electron transporter from NADPH to molecular oxygen and consists of a 22-kDa α-subunit (p22phox) and a large β-subunit termed Nox2, formerly known as gp91phox (1Babior B.M. Blood. 1999; 93: 1464-1476Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In human leukocytes, Nox2 is synthesized as a 65-kDa precursor in the Golgi apparatus, whereas mature Nox2 has a molecular mass of 91 kDa because of heavy glycosylation of the protein. The glycosylation pattern, however, has no impact on the function of the protein (3Parkos C.A. Allen R.A. Cochrane C.G. Jesaitis A.J. J. Clin. Investig. 1987; 80: 732-742Crossref PubMed Scopus (314) Google Scholar, 4Yu L. Zhen L. Dinauer M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27288-27294Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). The anchoring of the hemes in the cytochrome b558 occurs via four histidines located at positions 101, 115, 209, and 222 in Nox2 (5Yu L. Quinn M.T. Cross A.R. Dinauer M.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 7993-7998Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). Mutation of any of these histidines, resulting in the loss of a heme in Nox2, leads to a conformational change in the protein and not only prevents O–2 formation but also disrupts the interaction of Nox2 with p22phox (6Biberstine-Kinkade K.J. DeLeo F.R. Epstein R.I. LeRoy B.A. Nauseef W.M. Dinauer M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 31105-31112Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Recently, homologues of Nox2 have been identified (7Suh Y.A. Arnold R.S. Lassegue B. Shi J. Xu X. Sorescu D. Chung A.B. Griendling K.K. Lambeth J.D. Nature. 1999; 401: 79-82Crossref PubMed Scopus (1278) Google Scholar, 8Geiszt M. Kopp J.B. Varnai P. Leto T.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 8010-8014Crossref PubMed Scopus (710) Google Scholar, 9Cheng G. Cao Z. Xu X. van Meir E.G. Lambeth J.D. Gene. 2001; 269: 131-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (704) Google Scholar) and shown to be involved in O–2 formation in several organs, including the colon, the kidney, and the vasculature (10Lassegue B. Clempus R.E. Am. J. Physiol. 2003; 285: R277-R297Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). The homologue Nox1 has been suggested to have a role in the host defense of epithelial cells (11Geiszt M. Lekstrom K. Brenner S. Hewitt S.M. Dana R. Malech H.L. Leto T.L. J. Immunol. 2003; 171: 299-306Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar) and to contribute to signaling leading to hypertrophy and angiogenesis and even tumor formation (7Suh Y.A. Arnold R.S. Lassegue B. Shi J. Xu X. Sorescu D. Chung A.B. Griendling K.K. Lambeth J.D. Nature. 1999; 401: 79-82Crossref PubMed Scopus (1278) Google Scholar, 12Arbiser J.L. Petros J. Klafter R. Govindajaran B. McLaughlin E.R. Brown L.F. Cohen C. Moses M. Kilroy S. Arnold R.S. Lambeth J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 715-720Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar). Little is known about the functions of Nox4, but high expression of Nox4 has been suggested to induce senescence (8Geiszt M. Kopp J.B. Varnai P. Leto T.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 8010-8014Crossref PubMed Scopus (710) Google Scholar), and evidence indicates that Nox4 may also be involved in redox-mediated signal transduction in mesangial cells (13Gorin Y. Ricono J.M. Kim N.H. Bhandari B. Choudhury G.G. Abboud H.E. Am. J. Physiol. 2003; 285: F219-F229Crossref PubMed Scopus (242) Google Scholar), adipocytes (14Mahadev K. Motoshima H. Wu X. Ruddy J.M. Arnold R.S. Cheng G. Lambeth J.D. Goldstein B.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2004; 24: 1844-1854Crossref PubMed Scopus (441) Google Scholar), and endothelial cells (15Ago T. Kitazono T. Ooboshi H. Iyama T. Han Y.H. Takada J. Wakisaka M. Ibayashi S. Utsumi H. Iida M. Circulation. 2004; 109: 227-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (434) Google Scholar). It is well known that Nox2 associates with p22phox in phagocytes. It remains, however, to be determined whether Nox1 and Nox4 are also capable of undergoing such an association with p22phox. Recently, the first indirect evidence for such an interaction has been provided, as the function of Nox1 was observed to depend on the expression of p22phox (16Takeya R. Ueno N. Kami K. Taura M. Kohjima M. Izaki T. Nunoi H. Sumimoto H. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 25234-25246Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar). We set out to determine whether Nox1 and Nox4 exhibit a direct interaction with p22phox and studied the underlying mechanism. This task is, however, complicated by low expression levels of the different Nox homologues and by the lack of specific antibodies, particularly against Nox4. Consequently, plasmids coding for fusion proteins of NADPH oxidase subunits and variants of the green fluorescent protein (GFP) 1The abbreviations used are: GFP, green fluorescent protein; VSMC, vascular smooth muscle cells; FRET, fluorescence resonance energy transfer; yfp, yellow fluorescent protein; cfp, cyan fluorescent protein; HAoSMC, human aortic smooth muscle cells; IP, immunoprecipitation; ER, endoplasmic reticulum. were generated and transiently transfected into different cell types. This approach allows the observation of the tagged proteins by fluorescent microscopy and determination of potential co-localization of the fusion proteins in the cell. Moreover, with the aid of fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET), protein-protein interaction can be studied using laser scanning microscopy. Finally, specific antibodies directed against the GFP part of the constructs are available and thus allow the detection of the fusion proteins by Western blot analysis and even immunoprecipitation. Generation and Transfection of Fusion Constructs—Plasmids coding for rat full-length p22phox (GenBank™ accession number U18729), rat Nox1 (GenBank™, AF152963), rat Nox2 (GenBank™, AF298656), and rat FLAG-tagged Nox4 (GenBank™, AY027527) were provided by Dr. K. K. Griendling (Emory University, Atlanta, GA). The human p22phox plasmid was a gift from Dr. T. Leto (National Institutes of Health), and mouse Noxa1 and Noxo1 was kindly provided by Dr. B. Banfi (Geneva University Hospital, Geneva, Switzerland). pEcfp-N1 and pEyfp-N1, pYFP-MEM, pCFP-ER and pCFP-Endo were purchased from Clontech. Plasmids coding for full-length Nox1 and Nox2, tagged with yellow fluorescent protein (yfp) at the C-terminal end, and full-length p22-phox, tagged with cyan fluorescent protein (cfp) at the C-terminal end, were generated by overlay extension PCR. Full-length Nox4 tagged with yfp was constructed by cloning Nox4 into pEyfp-N1 and subsequently brought into the open reading frame by site-directed mutagenesis. For the fluorescence resonance energy transfer studies, mutants (A206K) exhibiting hydrophilic properties in the GFP variants were generated by site-directed mutagenesis as suggested previously by Zacharias et al. (17Zacharias D.A. Violin J.D. Newton A.C. Tsien R.Y. Science. 2002; 296: 913-916Crossref PubMed Scopus (1791) Google Scholar). H115L mutants of all Nox-yfp constructs and Nox-plasmids were generated by site-directed mutagenesis. All plasmids were confirmed by sequencing. Transfection of HEK293 (American Type Culture Collection, Manassas, VA) cells was carried out using the conventional calcium phosphate precipitation method. Human aortic smooth muscle cells (HAoSMC; Clonetics, via Biozym, Hess. Olderdorf, Germany) were transfected using magnetofection of magnetic nanoparticles (Chemicell, Berlin, Germany), according to the manufacturer's instructions as reported previously by others (18Scherer F. Anton M. Schillinger U. Henke J. Bergemann C. Kruger A. Gansbacher B. Plank C. Gene Ther. 2002; 9: 102-109Crossref PubMed Scopus (823) Google Scholar, 19Plank C. Schillinger U. Scherer F. Bergemann C. Remy J.S. Krotz F. Anton M. Lausier J. Rosenecker J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 384: 737-747Crossref PubMed Scopus (332) Google Scholar). Experiments were carried out 2 days after transfection. Immunoprecipitation and Western Blot Analysis—Cells were lysed in Triton lysis buffer containing Tris/HCl (pH 7.4, 20 mm), NaCl (150 mm), Na4P2O7 (10 mm), okadaic acid (10 nm), Na3VO4 (2 mm), leupeptin (2 μg/ml), pepstatin (2 μg/ml), trypsin inhibitor (10 μg/ml), phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (44 μg/ml), and Triton X-100 (1%v/v), left on ice for 10 min, and then centrifuged at 10,000 × g for 10 min. These extracts were used either directly for Western blot analysis or for immunoprecipitation. Immunoprecipitation (IP) experiments were carried out from the Triton-soluble fraction (500 μg in ∼700 μl), which contained about 30–50% of the total cellular p22phox and Nox content. Following preclearing with protein A/G-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences), proteins were precipitated using antibodies (1.5 μg) directed against Nox1 (affinity-purified rabbit polyclonal) (20Wingler K. Wunsch S. Kreutz R. Rothermund L. Paul M. Schmidt H.H. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 2001; 31: 1456-1464Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar), GFP (mouse monoclonal, Roche Applied Science) or p22phox (mouse monoclonal antibody 449, kindly provided by Dr. D. Roos, Sanquin Research at CLB, University of Amsterdam, The Netherlands) (21Verhoeven A.J. Bolscher B.G. Meerhof L.J. van Zwieten R. Keijer J. Weening R.S. Roos D. Blood. 1989; 73: 1686-1694Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Preclearings and post-IP supernatants were loaded on separate gels to confirm specificity of the bands in the immunoprecipitation and to ascertain identical amounts of protein in the IP. The latter was determined by staining for Erk1/2 using a rabbit polyclonal antibody (Cell Signaling Technology). Western Blot Analysis—Protein (20 μg) from Triton-soluble fractions or immunoprecipitates were heated (95 °C, 10 min) in Laemmli buffer, cleared by centrifugation, and separated on SDS-polyacrylamide gels, and then blotted onto nitrocellulose. Following blocking in nonfat dry milk (3%), proteins were detected using their respective antibodies. The monoclonal anti-Nox2 antibody α54.1 was kindly supplied by Dr. M. Quinn (Montana State University, Bozeman, MT). The anti-FLAG antibody was purchased from Sigma. Visualization was carried out using horseradish peroxidase-coupled secondary antibodies (Amersham Biosciences), a commercially available enhanced chemiluminescence kit (Amersham Biosciences), and x-ray-type photo films (Kodak). Confocal Microscopy and FRET Analysis—HAoSMC or HEK293 cells were seeded on glass coverslips (9 × 9 mm, coated with collagen or fibronectin, respectively) and transiently transfected with the fluorescent fusion construct. 48 h after transfection, the cells were fixed in phosphate-buffered paraformaldehyde solution (4%), washed in phosphate-buffered saline, and embedded in Dako-Fluoromount (Dako, Hamburg, Germany). Co-localization studies were carried out using a Zeiss laser-scanning confocal microscope LSM 510 META in multi-tracking mode to prevent interference of the dyes. FRET studies were performed at the same machine using living cells and a temperature-controlled setup and the method of acceptor bleaching reported previously by others (22Xia Z. Liu Y. Biophys. J. 2001; 81: 2395-2402Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (444) Google Scholar, 23Karpova T.S. Baumann C.T. He L. Wu X. Grammer A. Lipsky P. Hager G.L. McNally J.G. J. Microsc. 2003; 209: 56-70Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar). Briefly, two images were obtained using the multitracking mode (cfp excitation (458 nm); emission detection (475–525 nm), band-pass filter; yfp excitation (514 nm); emission detection (530 nm), long pass filter), high scan speed and low excitation energy. Subsequently, yfp was specifically bleached by the 514-nm laser line, set to high energy using 40 bleaching cycles. After this, two additional images were obtained. Regions of interest were marked in the bleached and nonbleached areas, and the intensity of the cfp fluorescence before and after bleaching was determined. The degree of FRET was expressed as the relative change in intensity of the cfp signal in the bleached region. A plasmid expressing a cfp/yfp-tagged fragment of dystrophin served as a positive control (24Badorff C. Berkely N. Mehrotra S. Talhouk J.W. Rhoads R.E. Knowlton K.U. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 11191-11197Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Determination of Reactive Oxygen Species Generation—Cells were seeded on 3.5-cm dishes, transiently transfected, and measurements were performed 2 days later. The cells were detached from the dish using phosphate-buffered saline/EDTA and suspended in 100 μl of HEPES-modified Tyrode's solution and transferred to tubes containing 400 μl of HEPES-modified Tyrode's solution and chemiluminescence enhancer. The radical production was determined using a Berthold LB 9505 chemiluminescence counter (Wildbad, Germany). As an enhancer for H2O2, luminol (100 μmol/liter) and horseradish peroxidase (1 unit/ml) was used. Expression of the Fluorescent Fusion Proteins—The NADPH oxidase-GFP fusion proteins were characterized by Western blot analysis. Rat Nox1-yfp, Nox2-yfp, Nox4-yfp, and p22phox-cfp were readily detectable using an anti-gfp antibody. Comparing the molecular mass of the constructs to that of the untagged proteins revealed the expected shift of 27 kDa, the molecular mass of GFP. The fusion proteins derived from the rat Nox sequences generated a distinct band, without signs of a glycosylation smear in HEK293 cells, and the molecular weight displayed equaled the mass predicted from the amino acid sequence (Fig. 1). In contrast, the typical glycosylation smear for Nox2 was detected by the anti-Nox2 antibody in HEK293 cells transfected with a plasmid coding for human Nox2 (Fig. 1E). All fusion proteins generated an additional band slightly smaller than that of YFP, which was recognized by the anti-GFP antibody, indicating that the fusion proteins were degraded to some extent. The anti-Nox1 antibody (20Wingler K. Wunsch S. Kreutz R. Rothermund L. Paul M. Schmidt H.H. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 2001; 31: 1456-1464Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar) also detected a band of 55 kDa in HEK293 cells, even in nontransfected cells, which corresponded to a strong band observed in Caco-2 cells. The latter cells highly expressed Nox1 and served as a positive control for this protein. As HEK293 cells express Nox1 on the mRNA level (9Cheng G. Cao Z. Xu X. van Meir E.G. Lambeth J.D. Gene. 2001; 269: 131-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (704) Google Scholar), one could speculate whether this signal corresponds to endogenous Nox1 in HEK293 cells. Similar results were obtained using a second Nox1 antibody (data not shown). Cellular Localization of the Fluorescent Fusion Proteins— Expression of p22phox-cfp, as well as Nox1-yfp, Nox2-yfp, and Nox4-yfp in HEK293 cells (Fig. 2) and HAoSMC (data not shown), produced a fluorescence pattern characteristic of cytoskeletal and intracellular membrane association. No interference between the fluorescence of cfp and yfp was observed with the filter setting used. Confocal microscopy of cells co-transfected with p22phox-cfp, together with the different Nox-yfp constructs, revealed marked co-localization of the cfp and yfp fluorescence (HEK293 cells) (Fig. 2) (data not shown). Immunodetection of the fusion proteins using antibodies directed against p22phox, Nox1, and Nox2 yielded co-localization of the fluorescence signals of the fusion proteins to the signal detected by the antibodies (data not shown). The fluorescence fusion proteins largely co-localized with grp-78 (goat polyclonal, Santa Cruz Biotechnology), a marker for endoplasmic reticulum (Fig. 3A). Co-expression of p22phox-cfp, Nox1-yfp, and Nox4-yfp colocated with the fluorescence obtained by an expression plasmid for a construct targeting cfp to the endoplasmic reticulum (cfp-ER-marker) but not to endosomes (cfp-endo-marker) or the plasma membrane (yfp-mem-marker) (Fig. 3B). To validate that this staining pattern was not a consequence of a disturbed processing of the Noxes due to the fluorescent tag but rather the native localization of the rat proteins in HEK293 cells, untagged rat Nox proteins were expressed and detected by specific antibodies. Using this approach, very similar staining patterns were observed, and no specific expression of p22phox, Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4 in the plasma membrane was observed (Fig. 4).Fig. 3Determination of the intracellular localization of p22phox-cfp and Nox isoforms-yfp fusion proteins.A, HEK293 cells were transfected with Nox2-yfp and p22phox-cfp. The endoplasmic reticulum was stained using an antibody directed against the marker protein grp78 and an appropriate secondary antibody coupled to the dye Alexa-546. Nuclei were stained with Topro-3 iodine (1 μmol/liter). B, transfection of HEK293 cells with either p22phox-cfp (cyan), Nox1-yfp (red), or Nox4-yfp (red) and co-transfection with plasmids coding for the following gfp marker fusion proteins: yfp membrane (yfp-Mem, red), cfp-endosomes (cfp-Endos, cyan), and cfp-endoplasmic reticulum (cfp-ER, cyan). Pink reflects co-localization.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT)Fig. 4Determination of the intracellular localization of wild-type p22phox and Nox isoforms. Transfection of HEK293 cells with plasmids coding for rat p22phox, Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4-FLAG and detection of these nonfluorescent proteins using the appropriate antibodies indicated, as well as a secondary antibody coupled to Alexa-546 nm. In the left panel of A, the nuclei were counterstained using the dye Topro-3 iodine. The plasma membrane was visualized by transfection of yfp membrane. B–D, in the left panels, specific staining of the antibody was depicted using the color red, whereas the background fluorescence, stained green, was used to visualize also the nontransfected cells. In the right panels of A–D, only the specific staining of the antibody used is depicted.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Determination of Protein-Protein Interaction by FRET Technique—The FRET technique is becoming a state-of-the-art tool to demonstrate a close (<10-nm) interaction between two proteins (22Xia Z. Liu Y. Biophys. J. 2001; 81: 2395-2402Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (444) Google Scholar). The method of acceptor bleaching, where the light emission of the higher energetic fluorophore is recovered after destruction of the lower energetic energy acceptor, allows the observation of FRET under static conditions (23Karpova T.S. Baumann C.T. He L. Wu X. Grammer A. Lipsky P. Hager G.L. McNally J.G. J. Microsc. 2003; 209: 56-70Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar). During the validation of this method, we observed that even native cfp and yfp, which are thought not to interact, have a tendency to exhibit false positive FRET. Recently, it has been demonstrated that such effects are a consequence of hydrophobic interactions of the GFPs and can be prevented by the introduction of hydrophilic amino acids into the GFP sequence (17Zacharias D.A. Violin J.D. Newton A.C. Tsien R.Y. Science. 2002; 296: 913-916Crossref PubMed Scopus (1791) Google Scholar). Consequently, all studies were performed using the A206K mutants of the GFP variants, which are not prone to such artifacts (17Zacharias D.A. Violin J.D. Newton A.C. Tsien R.Y. Science. 2002; 296: 913-916Crossref PubMed Scopus (1791) Google Scholar). Indeed, transfection of HEK293 cells or VSMC with cfp-A206K, together with yfp-A206 or cfp-A206K with Nox-yfp-A206K, did not yield a significant FRET signal. In contrast, transfection of p22phox-cfp-A206K with Nox1-yfp-A206K, Nox2-yfp-A206K, or Nox4-yfp-A206K resulted in a significant FRET, which was comparable between the Nox homologues studied in both cell types used. Nox-yfp constructs co-transfected with cfp-ER-marker did not result in FRET, demonstrating that the similar spatial distribution of p22phox with the Nox is not responsible for the FRET signal (Fig. 5). p22phox-cfp-A206K did not yield FRET together with yfp-A206K. Stabilization of p22phox by Nox Homologues—Interaction of p22phox with Nox2 in the NADPH oxidase of leukocytes has been shown to stabilize expression of the two proteins. To determine whether such a phenomenon is also evident for Nox1 and Nox4, plasmids coding for the native forms of these two proteins were transfected into HEK293 cells expressing p22phox-cfp. Nox1 and Nox4 both increased p22phox-cfp expression by ∼50% in these cells (Fig. 6). Transfection of yfp or empty vector had no effect on p22phox-cfp expression, excluding vector-vector interaction as a possible mechanism, whereas Nox1-yfp and Nox4-yfp also increased p22phox-cfp expression (Fig. 6). Co-immunoprecipitation of p22phox with Nox Homologues— To demonstrate that such a tight association of p22phox with the Nox homologues, as observed by FRET, also leads to protein interaction, co-immunoprecipitation experiments were performed in HEK293 cells. As this type of cell endogenously expresses p22phox, only Nox-yfp constructs were transfected for this part of the study. This task was complicated by the fact that the heavy and light chains of the immunoglobulins used for immunoprecipitation have molecular weights similar to those of the proteins of interest. With the aid of a mouse monoclonal anti-p22phox and an anti-GFP antibody, p22phox and the different Nox-yfp constructs, respectively, could be immunoprecipitated. Precipitation of p22phox revealed co-precipitation of all three Nox-yfp constructs studied, as observed by a band detected at the expected height by anti-GFP antibodies (Fig. 7), as well as by antibodies directed against Nox1 and Nox2 (data not shown). Accordingly, immunoprecipitation of the Nox-yfp constructs by an anti-GFP antibody yielded co-precipitation of endogenous p22phox (Fig. 7). Role of Heme Binding for the Interaction of p22phox with Nox Homologues—Loss of heme binding via exchange of the four histidines at positions 101, 115, 209, and 222 has been shown to disrupt the interaction of p22phox with Nox2. Interestingly, these histidines are highly conserved in all Nox homologues (9Cheng G. Cao Z. Xu X. van Meir E.G. Lambeth J.D. Gene. 2001; 269: 131-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (704) Google Scholar), which may suggest that they are also involved in heme binding in Nox1 and Nox4. In an attempt to study the role of these potentially heme-binding histidines in Nox1 and Nox4, we mutated the histidine at position 115 to leucine in Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4. The introduction of this mutation had no effect on the expression or localization of the Nox-yfp constructs, as determined by Western blot analysis and confocal microscopy (data not shown). Nevertheless, loss of histidine 115 in the Nox-yfp constructs completely prevented the interaction with p22phox; H115L-Nox1-yfp, H115L-Nox2-yfp, and H115L-Nox4-yfp could be immunoprecipitated by anti-GFP antibodies but did not co-precipitate p22phox. Vice versa, immunoprecipitation of p22phox failed to co-precipitate any of the three mutants (Fig. 7). Accordingly, co-transfection of p22phox-cfp with any of the H115L-Nox-yfp constructs did not result in a positive FRET (Fig. 5). Interaction of Nox1 with p22phox in Human Vascular Smooth Muscle Cells—The before-mentioned results suggest that an interaction of p22phox with Nox homologues occurs following transfection; i.e. in a situation of artificially high concentrations of the proteins of interest. To clarify the physiological relevance of this observation, interaction of endogenous Nox1 with p22phox was studied in HAoSMC. Endogenous Nox1 was immunoprecipitated using an affinity-purified rabbit peptide antibody. Interestingly, a protein of ∼75 kDa, which was detected by several anti-Nox1 antibodies directed against different epitopes, was immunoprecipitated by the Nox1 antibody from HAoSMC. Most importantly, p22phox was co-precipitated from HAoSMC by an anti-Nox1 antibody, demonstrating that the interaction of the two components also occurs at physiological protein levels (Fig. 8). Functional Interaction of p22phox with Nox1 and Nox4—In an attempt to demonstrate the functional interaction of p22phox with Nox2 homologues, the native rat plasmids were transfected in HEK293 cells in the presence and absence of rat p22phox and rat p22phox-cfp. As shown in figure 9, transfection of Nox4 into HEK293 cells, which endogenously express human p22phox, significantly increased radical generation. When rat p22phox or rat p22phox-cfp was transfected, H2O2 formation increased further by ∼3-fold. Interestingly, Nox4-dependent H2O2 formation was not affected by co-transfection of mouse Noxa1 and Noxo1 (Fig. 9), whereas these subunits had to be present to facilitate Nox1-dependent radical generation (data not shown). When the H115L mutant of Nox1 was transfected instead of the native constructs, no radical generation was observed, demonstrating that the Nox-p22phox complex (and the heme) is required for functional activity (data not shown). In the present study, we have determined whether a direct interaction of p22phox with Nox1 and Nox4 occurs. We observed that fluorescent constructs of p22phox co-localize with fluorescent Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4 and that this co-localization is so tight, it led to FRET. Moreover, p22phox co-precipitated Nox1-yfp, Nox2-yfp, and Nox4-yfp and vice versa, and this effect was critically dependent on histidine 115 in the Nox proteins. Furthermore, an anti-Nox1 antibody co-precipitated p22phox from native human aortic smooth muscle cells. Finally, p22phox is involved in Nox4-dependent radical formation. These observations demonstrate that the three Nox proteins studied are highly similar in their interaction with p22phox. The Nox1-, Nox2-, and Nox4-yfp fusion proteins expressed in HEK293 cells migrated at the molecular weight calculated from the amino acid sequence, and thus the heavy glycosylation, which is observed for human Nox2 in leukocyte, apparently does not occur in the constructs used. In human Nox2, glycosylation is thought to occur at three sites, positions 132–134, 149–151, and 240–242 (25Wallach T.M. Segal A.W. Biochem. J. 1997; 321: 583-585Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). In the current study, plasmids coding for the rat homologues of the oxidase subunit were used. Indeed, it has been reported that these glycosylated residues of Nox2 are not conserved in the rat homologue of the protein (26Bayraktutan U. Blayney L. Shah A.M. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 2000; 20: 1903-1911Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar), and transfection of wild-type rat gp91phox also did not exhibit the glycosylation shift. In line with this, it has been observed that, as a consequence of the different glycosylation pattern, the molecular weight of Nox2 varies considerably between species. Nox2 from mice has a molecular mass of only 58 kDa compared with the 91 kDa observed for human Nox2 (3Parkos C.A. Allen R.A. Cochrane C.G. Jesaitis A.J. J. Clin. Investig. 1987; 80: 732-742Crossref PubMed Scopus (314) Google Scholar, 27Bjorgvinsdottir H. Zhen L. Dinauer M.C. Blood. 1996; 87: 2005-2010Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It is controversial whether the endoplasmic reticulum form of Nox2 is associated with p22phox. In leukocytes, this was reported not to be the case (4Yu L. Zhen L. Dinauer M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27288-27294Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar), whereas in nonphagocyte cells overexpressing Nox2 and p22phox cells, similar to the model used in the present study, p22phox and Nox2 already interacted in the ER (4Yu L. Zhen L. Dinauer M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27288-27294Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). Similar observations were made regarding the localization of Nox2 in vascular endothelial cells (26Bayraktutan U. Blayney L. Shah A.M. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 2000; 20: 1903-1911Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar). Little is known concerning the intracellular localization of rat Nox homologues and, in particular, regarding the localization of Nox1 and Nox4. In the present study, the fusion proteins exhibited a reticular staining pattern comparable with endoplasmic reticulum and cytoskeletal association. Indeed, some of the membrane-bound NADPH oxidase subunits were found in the Triton-insoluble fraction. 2R. K. Ambasta, unpublished observations. This view is compatible with observations of a tight interaction of the NADPH oxidase with cytoskeletal signaling molecules (28Nauseef W.M. Volpp B.D. McCormick S. Leidal K.G. Clark R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 5911-5917Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29el Benna J. Ruedi J.M. Babior B.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6729-6734Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Human Nox1, in contrast, is partially localized in the plasma membrane, and this effect might be a consequence of the interaction with an Noxo1 (30Cheng G. Lambeth J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 4737-4742Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar). The main observation of the present study was that not only Nox2, but also Nox1 and Nox4, tightly interact with p22phox. Previously, it has been extensively demonstrated that the interaction of p22phox with Nox2 is required to form a functionally active enzyme in leukocytes (5Yu L. Quinn M.T. Cross A.R. Dinauer M.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 7993-7998Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). Recently, it was also demonstrated that co-transfection of p22phox together with Nox1 is required to facilitate Nox1-mediated O–2 generation in CHO-cells, which reportedly lack endogenous p22phox expression (16Takeya R. Ueno N. Kami K. Taura M. Kohjima M. Izaki T. Nunoi H. Sumimoto H. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 25234-25246Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar). Moreover, it has been shown that Nox1 is homologous enough to Nox2 that overexpression of Nox1 is able to compensate for the lack of Nox2 in cells derived from patients with chronic granulomatous disease and that Nox1 can be activated by the cytosolic components involved in Nox2 activation (11Geiszt M. Lekstrom K. Brenner S. Hewitt S.M. Dana R. Malech H.L. Leto T.L. J. Immunol. 2003; 171: 299-306Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar). In the present study, we extended this observation by demonstrating that also the rat Nox4-mediated radical production is increased upon transfection of rat p22phox. Interestingly, p22phox appears to be the only subunit required for Nox4-dependent radical generation. Cotransfection of Noxo1 and Noxa1, which are needed to support Nox1-dependent radical generation, was without effect. In the present study, we found no differences between the three rat Nox homologues regarding their ability to bind p22phox and their intracellular localization. Moreover, mutation of Nox histidines, equivalent to position 115 of human Nox2, disrupted p22phox association for all homologues, suggesting that heme binding is similar between the homologues. For the leukocyte oxidase, it has been shown that the heme is centrally important in the interaction of p22phox with Nox2 (4Yu L. Zhen L. Dinauer M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27288-27294Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). However, p22phox is not involved in heme binding per se (6Biberstine-Kinkade K.J. DeLeo F.R. Epstein R.I. LeRoy B.A. Nauseef W.M. Dinauer M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 31105-31112Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Rather, the hemes maintain the tertiary structure of Nox2 in such a way that the interaction with p22phox can occur. The results of the present study suggest that the Nox homologues studied are similar in this regard. Interestingly, almost nothing is known regarding the precise mechanism of p22phox and Nox2 association, and only epitope mapping provides some information regarding the amino acid sequences coming into proximity with each other (31Burritt J.B. DeLeo F.R. McDonald C.L. Prigge J.R. Dinauer M.C. Nakamura M. Nauseef W.M. Jesaitis A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 2053-2061Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 32Yamauchi A. Yu L. Potgens A.J. Kuribayashi F. Nunoi H. Kanegasaki S. Roos D. Malech H.L. Dinauer M.C. Nakamura M. Microbiol. Immunol. 2001; 45: 249-257Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Altogether, the function of p22phox is incompletely understood (2Vignais P.V. CMLS Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2002; 59: 1428-1459Crossref PubMed Scopus (631) Google Scholar). The components required for oxidase activity are not located in p22phox. FAD and the hemes are located in the Nox protein. Some controversy exists for the NADPH binding site, which is thought to be positioned in Nox2 (33Koshkin V. Pick E. FEBS Lett. 1993; 327: 57-62Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar), whereas others suggest localization in p67phox (34Paclet M.H. Coleman A.W. Vergnaud S. Morel F. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 9302-9310Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). p22phox is the binding partner of p47phox (35Sumimoto H. Hata K. Mizuki K. Ito T. Kage Y. Sakaki Y. Fukumaki Y. Nakamura M. Takeshige K. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 22152-22158Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar), the subunits required for oxidase assembly. Phosphorylation of p22phox in vitro has been demonstrated in the course of activation (36Regier D.S. Greene D.G. Sergeant S. Jesaitis A.J. McPhail L.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 28406-28412Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) but certainly is not central for oxidase activation. In contrast to the Nox homologues, which exhibit tissue-specific expression (9Cheng G. Cao Z. Xu X. van Meir E.G. Lambeth J.D. Gene. 2001; 269: 131-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (704) Google Scholar), p22phox mRNA is widely expressed in high abundance (2Vignais P.V. CMLS Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2002; 59: 1428-1459Crossref PubMed Scopus (631) Google Scholar, 37Parkos C.A. Dinauer M.C. Walker L.E. Allen R.A. Jesaitis A.J. Orkin S.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 3319-3323Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar), but p22phox protein levels in cells not expressing Nox homologues are low. Moreover, in some forms of chronic granulomatous disease, where Nox2 protein is not synthesized, p22phox protein is undetectable. Most likely the p22phox monomer is rapidly degraded, whereas heterodimer formation with Nox2 prevents this process (1Babior B.M. Blood. 1999; 93: 1464-1476Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Vignais P.V. CMLS Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2002; 59: 1428-1459Crossref PubMed Scopus (631) Google Scholar). In the present study, we observed that Nox1 and Nox4 also have the capacity to stabilize p22phox expression, as transfection of either wild-type or yfp-tagged Nox1 or Nox4 increased the expression of p22phox-cfp. The mechanism underlying this stabilization has not been determined so far, but it is important to realize that p22phox mRNA expression is not the limiting factor for p22phox protein expression and thus for the formation of the active cytochrome b558. Consequently, endogenous p22phox expression in HEK293 cells (which apparently also express Nox1 to Nox5 endogenously, see Ref. 9Cheng G. Cao Z. Xu X. van Meir E.G. Lambeth J.D. Gene. 2001; 269: 131-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (704) Google Scholar) was sufficient to form complexes with the Nox constructs transfected in the present study. In conclusion, in the present study we have demonstrated that p22phox forms complexes with Nox1, Nox2, and Nox4 and that mutation of histidine 115 in these Nox proteins disrupts the complex formation. We thank Sina Bätz, Annisudin Mohammed, and Florian Eich for excellent technical assistance. We thank Dr. William M. Nauseef for very helpful suggestions during the preparation of the manuscript.

Alzheimer's disease-associated β-amyloid peptides (Aβ) are generated by the sequential proteolytic processing of amyloid precursor protein (APP) by β- and γ-secretases. There is growing evidence that cholesterol- and sphingolipid-rich membrane microdomains are involved in regulating trafficking and processing of APP. BACE1, the major β-secretase in neurons is a palmitoylated transmembrane protein that resides in lipid rafts. A subset of APP is subject to amyloidogenic processing by BACE1 in lipid rafts, and this process depends on the integrity of lipid rafts. Here we describe the association of all four components of the γ-secretase complex, namely presenilin 1 (PS1)-derived fragments, mature nicastrin, APH-1, and PEN-2, with cholesterol-rich detergent insoluble membrane (DIM) domains of non-neuronal cells and neurons that fulfill the criteria of lipid rafts. In PS1-/-/PS2-/- and NCT-/- fibroblasts, γ-secretase components that still remain fail to become detergent-resistant, suggesting that raft association requires γ-secretase complex assembly. Biochemical evidence shows that subunits of the γ-secretase complex and three TGN/endosome-resident SNAREs cofractionate in sucrose density gradients, and show similar solubility or insolubility characteristics in distinct non-ionic and zwitterionic detergents, indicative of their co-residence in membrane microdomains with similar protein-lipid composition. This notion is confirmed using magnetic immunoisolation of PS1- or syntaxin 6-positive membrane patches from a mixture of membranes with similar buoyant densities following Lubrol WX extraction or sonication, and gradient centrifugation. These findings are consistent with the localization of γ-secretase in lipid raft microdomains of post-Golgi and endosomes, organelles previously implicated in amyloidogenic processing of APP. Alzheimer's disease, a neurodegenerative dementing disorder, is pathologically characterized by the cerebral deposition of 39–42 amino acid peptides termed β-amyloid (Aβ) 1The abbreviations used are: Aβ, β-amyloid; APP, amyloid precursor protein; PS, presenilin(s); NTF, N-terminal fragment; CTF, C-terminal fragment; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; TGN, trans-Golgi network; CHAPSO, 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-2-hydroxy-1-propanesulfonic acid; DIM, detergent-insoluble membrane; GTEL, Golgi/TGN/endosomes/lysosome-enriched membranes; MES, 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid; SNARE, soluble NSF attachment protein receptors; VAMP, vesicle-associated membrane protein; MβCD, methyl-β-cyclodextrin; GPI, glycosylphosphatidylinositol. peptides. Aβ is generated by the sequential processing of amyloid precursor protein (APP) by β- and γ-secretases (1Selkoe D.J. Physiol. Rev. 2001; 81: 741-766Crossref PubMed Scopus (5196) Google Scholar, 2Sisodia S.S. St George-Hyslop P.H. Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 2002; 3: 281-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (487) Google Scholar). BACE1, a transmembrane aspartyl protease is the major β-secretase, which cleaves APP within the extracellular/luminal domain, generating the N terminus of Aβ (3Vassar R. J. Mol. Neurosci. 2004; 23: 105-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar). A multimeric complex made of four transmembrane proteins is responsible for executing intramembraneous γ-secretase cleavage of APP C-terminal fragments (CTF) and releasing Aβ (4Iwatsubo T. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 2004; 14: 379-383Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). Genetic mutations in the APP, PSEN1, and PSEN2 genes are responsible for familial early-onset Alzheimer's disease (5Price D.L. Tanzi R.E. Borchelt D.R. Sisodia S.S. Annu. Rev. Genet. 1998; 32: 461-493Crossref PubMed Scopus (359) Google Scholar, 6Tanzi R.E. Bertram L. Neuron. 2001; 32: 181-184Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (423) Google Scholar). PSEN1 and PSEN2 encode polytopic membrane proteins presenilin 1 (PS1) and PS2, respectively, which as components of the γ-secretase complex play essential role in Aβ production (7De Strooper B. Saftig P. Craessaerts K. Vanderstichele H. Guhde G. Annaert W. Von Figura K. Van Leuven F. Nature. 1998; 391: 387-390Crossref PubMed Scopus (1560) Google Scholar, 8Naruse S. Thinakaran G. Luo J.-J. Kusiak J.W. Tomiata T. Iwatsubo T. Qian X. Ginty D.D. Price D.L. Borchelt D.R. Wong P.C. Neuron. 1998; 21: 1213-1221Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (333) Google Scholar). Considerable evidence suggests that familial Alzheimer's disease-linked PS1 and PS2 (PS) variants exert their pathogenic influence by selectively elevating the levels of highly fibrillogenic Aβ42 peptides (2Sisodia S.S. St George-Hyslop P.H. Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 2002; 3: 281-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (487) Google Scholar, 4Iwatsubo T. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 2004; 14: 379-383Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). In addition to APP proteolysis, PS play a crucial role in the intramembraneous γ-secretase cleavage of select type I membrane proteins including the homologues of APP (APLP1 and APLP2), Notch1, and homologues, Notch ligands Delta and Jagged, ErbB-4, CD44, low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein, N- and E-cadherins, nectin-1α, DCC, p75 neurotrophin receptor, etc. (see Ref. 9Thinakaran G. Parent A.T. Pharmacol. Res. 2004; 50: 411-418Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). In addition to the growing number of γ-secretase substrates, accumulating evidence from protein interaction and loss of function studies suggest that, aside from Aβ production, PS regulate diverse physiological functions (reviewed in Ref. 9Thinakaran G. Parent A.T. Pharmacol. Res. 2004; 50: 411-418Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). It is evident from recent studies that γ-secretase is a multi-protein complex comprised of PS1 (or PS2)-derived N- and C-terminal fragments (NTF and CTF), nicastrin, APH-1, and PEN-2 (10Takasugi N. Tomita T. Hayashi I. Tsuruoka M. Niimura M. Takahashi Y. Thinakaran G. Iwatsubo T. Nature. 2003; 422: 438-441Crossref PubMed Scopus (789) Google Scholar, 11Kimberly W.T. LaVoie M.J. Ostaszewski B.L. Chem. 2003; 278: 33992-34002Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). Nicastrin is a type I membrane protein, and PEN-2 and APH-1 are predicted to span the membrane two and eight times, respectively. Results from gene knockout and knockdown studies reveal that γ-secretase components assist each other during biogenesis and exit out of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), and all four components are required to undergo proper post-translational maturation and achieve stability (reviewed in Ref. 13De Strooper B. Lee H.J. Thinakaran G. Kim T.W. Yu G. Xu H. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 7850-7854Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar). The subcellular site(s) of γ-secretase cleavage of APP is a subject of considerable interest. There has been considerable epidemiological interest in the relationship between cholesterol and susceptibility to Alzheimer's disease (26Puglielli L. Tanzi R.E. Kovacs D.M. Nat. Neurosci. 2003; 6: 345-351Crossref PubMed Scopus (702) Google Scholar, 27Wolozin B. Neuron. 2004; 41: 7-10Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (237) Google Scholar). Cholesterol is the major sterol component in most mammalian membranes. Growing evidence implicates specialized cellular membrane microdomains rich in cholesterol and sphingolipids, termed lipid rafts, in a number of important biological functions (28Simons K. Toomre D. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 1: 31-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (5187) Google Scholar). DIM lipid rafts contribute to trafficking of proteins and lipids in the secretory and endocytic pathways by regulating vesicle sorting and formation (29Ikonen E. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2001; 13: 470-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (551) Google Scholar). Interestingly, a recent study reported that γ-secretase cleavage occurs in lipid rafts, but γ-secretase catalytic activity is independent of the presence of cholesterol (38Wada S. Morishima-Kawashima M. Qi Y. Misono H. Shimada Y. Ohno-Iwashita Y. Ihara Y. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 13977-13986Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Thus, it appears that APP processing within cholesterol-rich lipid rafts by secretases, and not the cholesterol levels per se, determines the levels of Aβ production. In this study, we have provided the first detailed characterization of lipid raft association of each of the components of γ-secretase, the enzyme, which plays an essential role in Alzheimer's disease-associated Aβ production. We report cholesterol-dependent association of significant amounts of each of the γ-secretase components to lipid rafts. Moreover, by subcellular fractionation, confocal microscopy, and immunoisolation methods, we show that endogenous PS1, nicastrin, APH-1, and PEN-2 associate with raft microdomains in post-Golgi and endosome membranes enriched in syntaxin 6, syntaxin 13, and VAMP4. These findings provide novel insights into the subcellular localization of γ-secretase, which has important implications in understanding the regulation of amyloidogenic processing of APP. Lipid Raft Isolation—Lipid rafts were isolated from nearly confluent cells grown in two 100-mm dishes as described previously (47Roper K. Corbeil D. Huttner W.B. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 582-592Crossref PubMed Scopus (483) Google Scholar, 48Brugger B. Graham C. Leibrecht I. Mombelli E. Jen A. Wieland F. Morris R. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 7530-7536Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 49Radeva G. Sharom F.J. Biochem. J. 2004; 380: 219-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) with some modifications. Briefly, cells were washed twice in phosphate-buffered saline, scraped into 1.5 ml of lysis buffer containing different detergents: 0.5% Lubrol WX (Lubrol 17A17; Serva) or 0.5% Brij-96V (Fluka) in 25 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), 150 mm NaCl, and 5 mm EDTA; 1% CHAPSO (Amresco) in 25 mm MES (pH 6.5) and 150 mm NaCl (MBS buffer); or 1% Triton X-100 in 25 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8) and 140 mm NaCl. All the lysis buffers were supplemented with a protease inhibitor mixture (Sigma) and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. Cells were homogenized by five passages through a 25-gauge needle. Lysates were adjusted to 45% final concentration of sucrose (final volume, 4 ml) and transferred to a 12-ml ultracentrifuge tube. A discontinuous sucrose gradient is then formed by sequentially layering 35% sucrose (4 ml) and 5% sucrose (4 ml), and the tubes were subject to ultracentrifugation at 39,000 rpm for 19 h in Beckman SW41 rotor at 4 °C. Twelve 1-ml fractions were collected from the top of the gradient using a fraction collector and equal volume of each fraction was analyzed by Western blotting. In some cases samples were concentrated by methanol/chloroform precipitation, or subject to immunoprecipitation before analysis. Mouse primary neurons were lysed in buffer containing 1% Lubrol WX in MES-buffered saline containing Complete protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Applied Science) at 4 °C and DIM were prepared as previously described (47Roper K. Corbeil D. Huttner W.B. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 582-592Crossref PubMed Scopus (483) Google Scholar). Lipid rafts were also isolated using a non-detergent method as described previously (50Waugh M.G. Lawson D. Hsuan J.J. Biochem. J. 1999; 337: 591-597Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). Briefly, cells grown to confluency were washed in cold phosphate-buffered saline and scraped into 2 ml of ice-cold MBS buffer containing 0.5 m sodium carbonate and protease inhibitors. Cells were disrupted on ice by Dounce homogenization (15 strokes) followed by sonication using 130 watt Ultrasonic Processor (Model GE130) set at amplitude 50 (twelve 5-s bursts). This homogenate was then subjected to fractionation as described above in sucrose gradient containing 250 mm sodium carbonate. Subcellular Fractionation—Cells from two 100-mm dishes were homogenized using a ball-bearing homogenizer with a 12 μm clearance and postnuclear supernatants were fractionated on sucrose density gradients as described previously (18Greenfield J.P. Tsai J. Gouras G.K. Hai B. Thinakaran G. Checler F. Sisodia S.S. Greengard P. Xu H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 742-747Crossref PubMed Scopus (331) Google Scholar). Twelve 1-ml fractions were collected from the top of the gradient using a fractionator, and 60 μl of each fraction were analyzed by Western blotting. To isolate lipid rafts from post-Golgi and endosome membranes, fraction 6 (enriched in Golgi/TGN/endosome/lysosome markers) from four gradients were pooled, diluted with 25 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), and 5 mm EDTA, and subject to centrifugation at 27,000 rpm for1hat4 °Cina SW41Ti rotor (Beckman Instruments). The resulting membrane pellet was resuspended in 0.5% Lubrol WX in 25 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4), 150 mm NaCl and 5 mm EDTA, homogenized by five passages through a 25-gauge needle, and subject to flotation density gradient centrifugation as described above. Immunoisolation of Raft Patches Using Magnetic Beads—Monoclonal antibody syntaxin 6, and affinity-purified PS1NT and αPS1Loop antibodies were bound to Dynabeads M-280 beads pre-coated with sheep anti-rabbit or anti-mouse IgG (Dynal) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Antibody OKT8 (recognizes CD8α) and affinity-purified polyclonal antibody STC261 (recognizes a luminal protein that is processed through the secretory pathway) were used as negative controls to establish the specificity of the immunoisolation procedure. Pooled lipid raft fractions 4 and 5 generated from Lubrol WX or non-detergent lysates were incubated with primary antibody-coated magnetic beads for 5 h with continuous slow rotation at 4 °C. Bound immunocomplexes were captured using a magnetic device and washed four times in 20 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) and 150 mm NaCl, and eluted in Laemmli buffer. Bound immunocomplexes and an aliquot of the input were analyzed by Western blotting. Immunofluorescence Labeling—Mouse embryonic fibroblasts or HeLa cells cultured on glass coverslips were fixed as described previously (51Hammond A.T. Glick B.S. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2000; 11: 3013-3030Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar) and blocked with 3% bovine serum albumin. Primary and secondary antibodies were diluted in phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.2% Tween 20 and 3% bovine serum albumin. Confocal images were acquired with a 100× oil immersion objective using a Zeiss laser scanning microscope (Pascal 5) and processed using MetaMorph software. Guggulsterone, derived from Commiphora mukul and used to treat obesity, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, atherosclerosis, and osteoarthritis, has been recently shown to antagonize the farnesoid X receptor and decrease the expression of bile acid-activated genes. Because activation of NF-κB has been closely linked with inflammatory diseases affected by guggulsterone, we postulated that it must modulate NF-κB activation. In the present study, we tested this hypothesis by investigating the effect of this steroid on the activation of NF-κB induced by inflammatory agents and carcinogens. Guggulsterone suppressed DNA binding of NF-κB induced by tumor necrosis factor (TNF), phorbol ester, okadaic acid, cigarette smoke condensate, hydrogen peroxide, and interleukin-1. NF-κB activation was not cell type-specific, because both epithelial and leukemia cells were inhibited. Guggulsterone also suppressed constitutive NF-κB activation expressed in most tumor cells. Through inhibition of IκB kinase activation, this steroid blocked IκBα phosphorylation and degradation, thus suppressing p65 phosphorylation and nuclear translocation. NF-κB-dependent reporter gene transcription induced by TNF, TNFR1, TRADD, TRAF2, NIK, and IKK was also blocked by guggulsterone but without affecting p65-mediated gene transcription. In addition, guggulsterone decreased the expression of gene products involved in anti-apoptosis (IAP1, xIAP, Bfl-1/A1, Bcl-2, cFLIP, and survivin), proliferation (cyclin D1 and c-Myc), and metastasis (MMP-9, COX-2, and VEGF); this correlated with enhancement of apoptosis induced by TNF and chemotherapeutic agents. Overall, our results indicate that guggulsterone suppresses NF-κB and NF-κB-regulated gene products, which may explain its anti-inflammatory activities.

Previous studies show that feedback inhibition of bile acid production by bile acids is mediated by multiple mechanisms, including activation of pregnane X receptor (PXR). Consistent with these studies, the antibiotic rifampicin, a ligand for human PXR, reduces hepatic bile acid levels in cholestasis patients. To delineate the mechanisms underlying PXR-mediated suppression of bile acid biosynthesis, we examined the functional cross-talk between human PXR and HNF-4, a key hepatic activator of genes involved in bile acid biosynthesis including the cholesterol 7-α hydroxylase (CYP7A1) and sterol 12-α hydroxylase (CYP8B1) genes. Treatment with rifampicin resulted in repression of endogenous human CYP7A1 expression in HepG2 cells that was reversed by PXR small interfering RNA. The coactivator PGC-1 enhanced transcriptional activity of HNF-4, and this enhancement was suppressed by rifampicin-activated PXR. Endogenous PGC-1 from mouse liver extracts bound to PXR, and recombinant PGC-1 directly interacted with both PXR and HNF-4 in vitro. Rifampicin-dependent interaction of PXR with PGC-1 was shown in cells by coimmunoprecipitation, and intranuclear localization studies using confocal microscopy provided further evidence for this interaction. In chromatin immunoprecipitation studies, rifampicin treatment did not inhibit HNF-4 binding to the native promoters of CYP7A1 and CYP8B1 but resulted in dissociation of PGC-1 and concomitant gene repression. Most interestingly, these rifampicin effects were also observed in the phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase gene that contains a functional HNF-4-binding site and is central to hepatic gluconeogenesis. Our study suggests that ligand-activated PXR interferes with HNF-4 signaling by targeting the common coactivator PGC-1, which underlies physiologically relevant inhibitory cross-talk between drug metabolism and cholesterol/glucose metabolism. By using a combination of chromatin immunoprecipitation assays and promoter microarrays, Young and co-workers (21Odom D.T. Zizlsperger N. Gordon D.B. Bell G.W. Rinaldi N.J. Murray H.L. Volkert T.L. Biol. 2001; : 1393-1403Crossref PubMed Scopus (868) Google Scholar) of conditional HNF-4 null mice demonstrated that HNF-4 was crucial to the expression of numerous hepatic genes and, especially, was a major in vivo regulator of genes involved in lipid homeostasis. HNF-4 is central to cholesterol and glucose/energy metabolism because it is a key activator for basal hepatic expression of CYP7A1 and CYP8B1 genes and glucose-6-phosphatase and PEPCK genes, which play central roles in bile acid biosynthesis and hepatic gluconeogenesis, respectively (1Zhang M. By using CYP7A1, CYP8B1, and PEPCK genes as model systems, we have studied molecular mechanisms by which human PXR suppresses hepatic bile acid production and gluconeogenesis. Here we show that ligand-activated PXR attenuates HNF-4 signaling by competing for the common coactivator PGC-1 in hepatic cells and thus causes dissociation of endogenous PGC-1 from HNF-4-bound promoter chromatin, resulting in concomitant gene repression. Our study implies that inhibitory cross-talk mediated by these orphan nuclear receptors may be physiologically relevant in drug and cholesterol/glucose metabolism. Kim H. Miao J. Bhalla S. Bae Y. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2004; 24: 7707-7719Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar). Briefly, harvested cells were resuspended in lysis buffer (20 mm K+-Hepes, pH 8.0, 0.2 mm EDTA, 5% glycerol, 100 mm NaCl, 0.1% Nonidet P-40, 0.25% sodium deoxycholate, 1 mm NaF, 1 mm sodium orthovanadate, 1 mm DTT, and protease inhibitors). After incubation on ice for 10 min followed by sonication and centrifugation, cell extracts were precleared by incubation with 60 μl of a 25% protein A-Sepharose slurry for 30 min at 4 °C and were then incubated with 3–5 μg of either IgG or Gal4 DBD antisera for 4 h to overnight at 4 °C. Immune complexes were collected by incubation with 30 μl of a 25% protein A-Sepharose slurry for 1 h followed by centrifugation. Immunoprecipitates were washed five times with lysis buffer and subjected to Western blotting. Me2SO or 10 μm rifampicin was added during immunoprecipitation and washing steps. Subnuclear Localization Study Using Confocal Microscopy—COS-1 cells were grown on glass coverslips in 6-well plates and cotransfected with either 0.5 μg of GFP or GFPPXR along with expression plasmids for PGC-1 or empty vector. After 24 h, cells were treated with 10 μm rifampicin or Me2SO for 3–4 h in serum-free media. Cells were fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde in phosphate-buffered saline for 20 min, mounted with mounting medium that contained propidium iodide, and subjected to confocal microscopy (Zeiss LSM 510). Peripherin is a neuronal intermediate filament associated with inclusion bodies in motor neurons of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). A possible peripherin involvement in ALS pathogenesis has been suggested based on studies with transgenic mouse overexpressors and with a toxic splicing variant of the mouse peripherin gene. However, the existence of peripherin gene mutations in human ALS has not yet been documented. Therefore, we screened for sequence variants of the peripherin gene (PRPH) in a cohort of ALS patients including familial and sporadic cases. We identified 18 polymorphic variants of PRPH detected in both ALS and age-matched control populations. Two additional PRPH variants were discovered in ALS cases but not in 380 control individuals. One variant consisted of a nucleotide insertion in intron 8 (PRPHIVS8–36insA), whereas the other one consisted of a 1-bp deletion within exon 1 (PRPH228delC), predicting a truncated peripherin species of 85 amino acids. Remarkably, expression of this frameshift peripherin mutant in SW13 cells resulted in disruption of neurofilament network assembly. These results suggest that PRPH mutations may be responsible for a small percentage of ALS, cases and they provide further support of the view that neurofilament disorganization may contribute to pathogenesis. One variant consisted of a nucleotide insertion in intron 8 (PRPHIVS8–36insA), whereas the other one consisted of a 1-bp deletion within exon 1 (PRPH228delC), predicting a truncated peripherin species of 85 amino acids. Remarkably, expression of this frameshift peripherin mutant in SW13 cells resulted in disruption of neurofilament network assembly. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) 1The abbreviation used are: ALS, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; FALS, familial ALS; SALS, sporadic ALS; PRPH, peripherin; IF, intermediate filament; NF-H, neurofilament heavy; NF-L, neurofilament light; NF-M, neurofilament medium.1The abbreviation used are: ALS, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; FALS, familial ALS; SALS, sporadic ALS; PRPH, peripherin; IF, intermediate filament; NF-H, neurofilament heavy; NF-L, neurofilament light; NF-M, neurofilament medium. is a common, usually fatal, adult onset neurodegenerative disorder characterized by degeneration of motor neurons in the cortex, brainstem, and spinal cord (1Tandan R. Bradley W.G. Ann. Neurol. 1985; 18: 271-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (339) Google Scholar). Dysfunction and death of these motor neurons lead to progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, and ultimately paralysis and death, usually within 3–5 years after disease onset (2Mulder D.W. Kurland L.T. Offord K.P. Beard C.M. Neurology. 1986; 36: 511-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (343) Google Scholar). The disease occurs in sporadic (SALS) and familial (FALS) forms with an estimated incidence of ∼2 per 100,000. Although most cases of ALS are sporadic, some families demonstrate a clinically indistinguishable form of ALS with clear Mendelian inheritance and high penetrance (FALS).
